abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Trade Reform and
            Competitiveness Project for Senegal were as follows: the
            outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that the partnering and working
            together in common cause of the Lender and Borrower in
            preparing, adopting, monitoring, implementing and evaluating
            the various components of the credit account for the
            satisfactory ratings. The key here was the linkage of the
            credit to internal reforms currently being undertaken by the
            Government of Senegal (GOS) and the level of communications
            and collaboration established. The credit was part of an
            existing comprehensive commitment on the part of the GOS to
            embark on trade and tax reform in its fight against poverty.
            The desired goal was consistent with the objective of this
            credit being a more open and competitive economy with its
            emphasis on demonstrated its commitment to reform as set out
            in 3.3.1. Keeping disbursement conditions few in number and
            focused on specific objectives rather than on actions
            requiring micro-management of project components allowed for
            satisfactory implementation of this credit. The key here was
            the emphasis on results leaving the means to the borrower.
            The key to successful implementation was the challenge of
            getting the GOS to take ownership of the process. Managing
            and assessing the risks at the outset are also important
            ingredients for successful implementation. The facts that
            implementation of similar management information systems had
            been implemented elsewhere and that subscription to West
            African Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU) tenets
            prohibited imposition of new import protection measures
            served as mitigating risk factors.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Trade Reform and Competitiveness
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the strategic context as
            identified in 1997, the Trade Reform and Competitiveness
            Credit Project in Senegal, will assist the Government in its
            regional integration, through macroeconomic stabilization,
            and the promotion of private sector development. The project
            will improve competitiveness, through trade liberalization,
            easing trade and taxation, and supporting regulatory
            programs that promote competitive pricing of public utility
            inputs to the productive sector. The first tranche of the
            operation, will finance the implementation of the tariff,
            and tax reforms, adjustments in customs, and tax procedures,
            and the establishment of performance criteria for these
            reforms. The second tranche, will support an adjustment
            program, with full data links between the customs, and tax
            departments. The legislative framework will be developed, to
            define the regulatory system for public utilities, and
            infrastructure. Nonetheless, competitiveness measures rely
            on an integrated plan for Government data systems, which may
            encounter implementation difficulties, and, some economic
            entities may try to regain their lost import protection.
            These risks would be mitigated by sound competitive
            practices, successfully integrated in developing countries,
            while the West African Economic and Monetary Union, restrict
            the recourse to increase import protection.
